deliberation: I checked whether the language of tearing, striking, healing, and binding is literal or figurative. Given the broader Hosea context (YHWH as lion and Israel as the wounded nation), the bodily injury and medical treatment terms function metaphorically for national judgment and restoration. The verse contains two closely parallel but distinct metaphoric cola.

instances.english_text: for He has torn, and He will heal us
target: Israel’s experience of devastating divine judgment and hoped-for restoration
national covenant fate
Israel’s covenant history with God
vehicle: a body torn by an attacker and then healed by a healer
ground: severe damage inflicted, followed by restorative care from the same agent
transition from pain to healing
experiences of harm and recovery
posture: penitent hope that the God who harmed will also heal
repentant trust in divine mercy after judgment
human response to divine discipline
instances.explanation: National calamity brought by God is depicted as being torn like a victim of an attack, and God’s coming restoration is depicted as medical healing. The physical injury/healing imagery stands metaphorically for spiritual and socio-political judgment and renewal.

instances.english_text: He has struck, and He will bind us up
target: Israel’s suffering under divine blows and subsequent restoration
experience of punishment and healing
Israel’s spiritual and historical condition
vehicle: a person struck and then bandaged by a healer
wounding and bandaging of a body
ground: painful blows are followed by careful treatment and dressing of the wound
movement from inflicted injury to protective care
patterns of chastisement and compassionate repair
posture: acknowledgment of deserved blows combined with confidence in God’s healing intention
penitent yet trusting stance toward divine correction
human attitude under disciplinary suffering
instances.explanation: The nation’s afflictions from God are portrayed as bodily blows, and God’s restorative action as binding up a wound. This extends the medical/judicial metaphor of God as both punisher and healer.

deliberation: I examined whether the time expressions and the verbs 'revive' and 'raise up' are literal or figurative. Given Hosea’s corporate focus and lack of explicit individual resurrection context, the language is best read as a metaphor for national restoration after judgment, not literal bodily resurrection.

instances.hebrew_text: יְחַיֵּנוּ מִיֹּמָיִם בַּיּוֹם הַשְּׁלִישִׁי יְקִמֵנוּ וְנִחְיֶה לְפָנָיו
instances.english_text: He will revive us after two days; on the third day He will raise us up, and we shall live before Him
target: Israel’s anticipated restoration after a brief period of judgment
national renewal and re-establishment
the covenant people’s historical destiny
vehicle: a dead or gravely ill person revived and raised up to stand alive before someone
revival from deathlike illness and being physically raised
ground: moving from a condition like death to renewed life and standing in someone’s presence
transition from extreme weakness to vigorous life
patterns of restoration from ruin
posture: confident expectation that God will quickly turn deadly judgment into renewed life
hopeful trust in rapid divine intervention
faith stance toward God’s saving power
instances.explanation: The community’s recovery after judgment is portrayed as being revived from near-death and raised up on the third day. The bodily resurrection/recovery imagery functions metaphorically for corporate restoration in history.

deliberation: I looked for comparisons marked by כ- (‘like/as’) and for any personification. The verse explicitly compares God’s coming to dawn and to rain/latter rain. These are clear similes that use natural phenomena to picture the certainty and life-giving nature of God’s presence.

instances.english_text: His going forth is sure like the dawn
target: the reliability and regularity of God’s self-disclosure/coming
God’s saving intervention
divine presence in history
vehicle: daybreak as a regular natural event
ground: both occur predictably and dispel darkness/uncertainty
certainty and illuminating effect
reliable transitions from darkness to light
posture: assured confidence in God’s dependable coming
trusting expectation
human faith in divine faithfulness
instances.explanation: God’s ‘going forth’ is explicitly likened to the dawn, stressing its certainty and illuminating, hope-bringing character through a natural-schedule comparison.

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָבֹא כַגֶּשֶׁם לָנוּ כְּמַלְקוֹשׁ יוֹרֶה אָרֶץ
instances.english_text: He will come to us like the rain, like the latter rain that waters the earth

divine blessing and renewal

ground: both bring refreshment, fertility, and sustained life to a parched environment
life-giving, restorative influence
provision that enables growth and fruitfulness
posture: eager longing for God’s refreshing visitation
hopeful desire for renewal
dependence on God as life-giver
instances.explanation: God’s coming is likened to rain and specifically to the latter rain that waters the earth, emphasizing His role in refreshing and making His people fruitful, as rain does for the land.

deliberation: I noted the rhetorical question and then looked for comparative markers. The verse directly compares Ephraim’s and Judah’s covenant love/loyalty (חֶסֶד) to a morning cloud and early dew that quickly vanish, yielding two related but distinct similes.

instances.english_text: your loyalty is like a morning cloud

human faithfulness to God
moral-spiritual character of the covenant people
vehicle: a morning cloud that appears briefly and then dissipates
ground: both appear promising at first but vanish quickly without lasting effect
ephemerality and unreliability
instability of what initially looks substantial
posture: divine frustration at shallow, fleeting devotion
critical evaluation of human unfaithfulness
prophetic lament over unreliable loyalty
instances.explanation: Israel’s covenant love is explicitly compared to a morning cloud that soon disappears, emphasizing its transient and unreliable nature.

instances.english_text: and like the dew that early goes away

persistence (or lack thereof) of human devotion
covenant behavior of the people

short duration and lack of staying power
failure to endure under changing conditions
posture: divine disappointment with transient obedience
judgmental stance toward superficial religiosity
prophetic exposure of shallow commitment
instances.explanation: Their loyalty is likened to early dew that soon disappears, reinforcing the picture of ephemeral faithfulness that cannot be relied upon.

deliberation: I focused on the unusual verbs ‘hewn’ and ‘slain’ applied to prophetic activity, and on the imagery of judgment as light. These clearly go beyond literal description of physical violence and instead figuratively depict the impact and revelation of God’s word and judgment.

divine disciplinary action via prophecy
God’s governance of His covenant community

manual work on stone or wood

severity and transformative impact
painful but purposeful alteration
posture: God portrayed as an artisan-judge reshaping or cutting down His people through words
assertive, disciplinary stance
divine resolve to reform or remove what is corrupt
instances.explanation: God’s use of prophets to confront Israel is pictured as hewing with tools, a metaphor for the forceful, chiseling effect of prophetic words on the people.

spiritual and covenantal ruin brought by divine pronouncement
outcome of rejecting prophetic warning

instances.explanation: God’s pronouncements through the prophets are said to ‘slay’ the people, a metaphor (with hyperbolic force) portraying His word as a lethal weapon executing judgment.

instances.english_text: and your judgment will go forth as light
target: the manifestation and effects of God’s judicial decision against His people
divine judgment becoming evident
God’s moral governance
vehicle: light going forth and illuminating darkness
ground: both expose what is hidden and make reality unmistakably clear
revelatory clarity and inescapability
contrast between hiddenness and open exposure

instances.explanation: God’s ‘judgment’ is depicted as ‘light’ going forth, a metaphor that presents His judicial action as bringing illuminating clarity to moral reality.

deliberation: I considered whether the verse is purely propositional or figurative. The contrast ‘steadfast love, not sacrifice; knowledge of God rather than burnt offerings’ uses (1) a conventional Semitic hyperbolic/idiomatic ‘not X but Y’ construction to express preference, and (2) offerings as a metonymy for the broader cultic system and outward religiosity.

instances.hebrew_text: חֶסֶד חָפַצְתִּי וְלֹא־זָבַח וְדַעַת אֱלֹהִים מֵעֹלוֹת
instances.english_text: For I desire steadfast love, and not sacrifice; knowledge of God rather than burnt offerings
target: God’s prioritization of inner covenant loyalty over external ritual performance
relative value of ethical devotion versus cultic acts
true worship in Israel
vehicle: the negation/contrast formula ‘not X but Y’ used to mean ‘Y much more than X’
ground: stated exclusion of one item heightens the other’s importance while not literally abolishing the first
exaggerated contrast to stress priority
communication of value through overstatement
posture: strongly corrective of ritualism, emphasizing what really matters to God
prophetic critique of misplaced religious emphasis
divine reorientation of values
instances.explanation: The ‘not sacrifice… rather than burnt offerings’ construction is a hyperbolic idiom: God is not absolutely rejecting sacrifices He Himself commanded, but overstating the contrast to stress that covenant love and knowledge of God are vastly more important.

target: the entire system of external ritual worship in Israel
cultic observance without necessary inner devotion
Israel’s religious practice
vehicle: specific sacrificial rites: slaughter offerings and burnt offerings
ground: the particular offerings stand for, and summarize, the broader sacrificial system
part representing the whole (rituals for full cult)
representative emblem of religious practice
posture: critical of reliance on external rituals as if they were the entirety of devotion
prophetic warning against formalism
divine insistence on inner reality behind symbols
instances.explanation: ‘Sacrifice’ and ‘burnt offerings’ function metonymically for the whole cultic system and outward religiosity, which God sets in contrast to genuine covenant love and knowledge.

deliberation: I examined the debated phrase כְאָדָם—whether it refers to ‘Adam’ or ‘human beings’. In either case it is introduced with כ- (‘like/as’), forming a simile that likens Israel’s covenant breach to a prior or typical human covenant breach. The rest (‘transgressed the covenant’, ‘dealt treacherously’) is standard covenant language, not overtly figurative beyond normal lexical extension.

instances.english_text: But they, like Adam / like men, have transgressed the covenant
target: Israel’s act of breaking God’s covenant
covenant infidelity of the nation
moral behavior of the covenant community
vehicle: Adam’s (or generic humans’) prior act of transgression
ground: both involve violating a divinely given command or covenant obligation
shared character of disloyalty and rebellion
typical human failure in relation to God
posture: indicting Israel as acting in a thoroughly ‘Adam-like’ or typically humanly unfaithful way
prophetic censure via comparison
divine disapproval of Israel’s conformity to a sinful pattern
instances.explanation: The verse explicitly compares Israel’s covenant violation to that of Adam or of ordinary humans, using a simile to underscore that Israel’s behavior is not exceptional but matches an archetypal pattern of human unfaithfulness.

deliberation: I checked for place-person metonymy and vivid descriptive imagery. ‘Gilead’ functions for its inhabitants, and ‘tracked with blood’ (עֲקֻבָּה מִדָּם) is a graphic metaphor for pervasive bloodshed, likely also hyperbolic, envisioning the city as covered in bloody footprints.

instances.english_text: Gilead is a city of evildoers

inhabitants’ collective behavior
population of an Israelite region

ground: the place is identified by, and so represents, the dominant character of its inhabitants
association of location with moral quality of its people
use of toponyms as shorthand for populations
posture: condemning an entire community by naming its place as morally corrupt
prophetic denunciation of a region
divine judgment articulated through place-labeling
instances.explanation: ‘Gilead’ stands metonymically for its inhabitants, and the city is labeled by the evil of those who live there, making the toponym function as a moral designation.

target: the extent and pervasiveness of violence and bloodshed in Gilead
moral and social state of the city
degree of communal injustice
vehicle: a surface covered in footprints stained with blood

graphic evidence of repeated wrongdoing

prophetic horror at systemic bloodshed
moral revulsion given vivid visual form
instances.explanation: The phrase pictures the city as literally tracked with blood, a striking metaphor (with hyperbolic force) for the ubiquity of violence and murder in Gilead.

deliberation: I looked for explicit comparisons. The priests are directly compared to a band of robbers lying in wait on the road to Shechem. The main figure is a simile likening corrupt priests to highway bandits; the murder language itself can plausibly be literal.

instances.english_text: And like the lurking of a band of robbers is the company of priests
target: the treacherous, predatory behavior of the priests
moral character and actions of the priestly group
religious leadership in Israel
vehicle: a band of highway robbers lying in ambush
ground: both prey upon the vulnerable in secretive, violent ways and betray trust
treachery, predation, and violence
exploitation of others for selfish gain
posture: a scathing denunciation comparing priests to criminals
prophetic outrage at religious corruption
divine condemnation of abusive leadership
instances.explanation: The ‘company of priests’ is likened to a lurking band of robbers, a simile that exposes their treacherous and predatory conduct by comparing them to violent criminals.

deliberation: Given Hosea’s consistent use of sexual language (‘whoredom’, ‘defiled’) for idolatry and covenant betrayal, I took ‘fornication’ and ‘defiled’ here as primarily metaphorical for spiritual apostasy rather than merely literal sexual sin.

instances.english_text: There is whoredom in Ephraim; Israel is defiled
target: Israel’s idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness toward God
spiritual/religious apostasy
covenant relationship between God and His people
vehicle: sphere of sexual morality and purity laws
ground: both involve betrayal of an exclusive relational commitment and result in impurity and shame
unfaithfulness, pollution, and broken loyalty
violation of an intended exclusive bond
posture: portraying Israel’s idolatry as disgusting marital infidelity
prophetic moral disgust and grief
divine jealousy for covenant fidelity
instances.explanation: ‘Whoredom’ and ‘defiled’ are metaphorical, using the imagery of sexual immorality and ritual impurity to depict Israel’s spiritual infidelity through idolatry and covenant betrayal.

deliberation: I examined ‘harvest’ to see if it is literal or a familiar judgment metaphor. In prophetic literature, harvest often symbolizes judgment. I also noted the collocation ‘restore the fortunes’ (שׁוּב שְׁבוּת) as a standard idiom for comprehensive restoration, not a literal physical turning.

historical outworking of divine justice

inevitable reaping of what has been sown
principle of consequences following causes
posture: warning Judah that a time of reckoning is fixed

instances.explanation: ‘Harvest’ metaphorically denotes the time when Judah will reap the consequences of its behavior, drawing on the agricultural image of reaping what has been sown to depict judgment or recompense.

instances.english_text: when I restore the fortunes (captivity) of My people

vehicle: returning something that has been taken away

prophetic assurance of future grace
instances.explanation: The phrase ‘restore the fortunes’ (lit. ‘turn back the captivity/fortunes’) is a set idiom and metonymy for God’s broad restoration of His people’s well-being, not only literal release from captivity.
